author: MatejKafka
body:
## Steps to reproduce
```powershell
function Test {
	[CmdletBinding()]
	param()
	
	Test2
}

function Test2 {
	[CmdletBinding()]
	param()
	
	NonexistentCommand
}

Test
```

## Expected behavior

Independently from the current value of `$ErrorActionPreference`, thrown error always points to the line in `Test2`:
```none
NonexistentCommand:
Line |
  12 |      NonexistentCommand
     |      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | The term 'NonexistentCommand' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
```

## Actual behavior

For `$ErrorActionPreference = 'Continue'`, the correct error is printed. For `'Stop'`, the following error position is shown instead:
```none
Test2:
Line |
   5 |      Test2
     |      ~~~~~
     | The term 'NonexistentCommand' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
```

This is quite inconvenient for debugging. When `[CmdletBinding()]` is not set, everything works as expected for both error action settings.

It seems PowerShell tries to make cmdlets opaque, but only does so when `$ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop'`, which doesn't make sense to me.

title: Incorrect position of error when `$ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop'`, `[CmdletBinding()]` is present and something fails on language level
